title: Bots in ARAM and proliferation of such.
body:
I KNOW these are getting reported.  their behaviour is dead easy to spot in game, there's only about 2-3 variations of it (buying an oracles right at the start with no stealth on the other team is one of the early signs (with a delay of about 30-40 seconds in town at the start on same version)).  

But I've had games recently where I've seen 2 bots on one side and 3 on the other. That makes for a SUCKY game whoever wins.  If we could get some faster policing of these accounts, and possibly something like ip (or better mac address) bans on them would be VERY much appreciated.  These things are more destructive to a good game then gold farming was in WoW. cause gold-farmers just sold crap for real money, THESE guys make it impossible to have a fun game while they do it.

replies.body:
I'm fairly certain that this could be largely fixed with a small amount of effort.
I had a few aram's this morning, got a bunch of bots in them, roughly 9 in two games.
Fine, so I reported them.  While being bored at work this afternoon I jumped on op.gg to have a look at these bots.
And it was really easy to see a pattern, the account levellers log a mass of bots on at times when there are not many other people on and spam a bunch of aram's.
And there were quite a few games in these bot's history that were all bots.  I'd imagine the idea being if the whole game is bots, there's no one to report them.

It was also very easy to find new bots using op.gg, as they spam a few games in a row their "recently played with..." list is just full of other bots. In less than 10 minutes on the website I had pages open of over 20 bots all under level 30, snowball and cleanse summoners, only ever played arams, all with the same naming convention (an actual name with a few random letters added on) many showing purchasing of oracles extract.
I could have carried on finding more without much trouble.

So simply reviewing logs of large increases of aram queues at low traffic times would undoubtedly provide riot with a large list of bots.
Once you have that list, review their match history and you'll find even more. 
It may be possible to identify a IP or mac address to ban with such a large sample size? But I don't know much about that side of things.

I'm aware that the account levellers would eventually change tactics and new methods would have to be found to combat them.
I will admit I'm a little bit confused as to why this hasn't already been done.
If some nobody like me can identify a large group of bots, then what excuse does the player behaviour team have, with all their reporting tools at their disposal, for not doing so?
If anyone is in a position to know the answer to that, I'd love to hear it.
